_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This executive summary details Texas Instruments compliance with the EPAs Risk Management Program (RMP) requirements at the Lehi Fabrication facility (Texas Instruments - LFAB). In line with its Environmental, Safety, and Health (ESH) Policy, TI is committed to maintaining a safe workplace and minimizing environmental impact through the responsible handling of hazardous chemicals. TIs Risk Management Program includes hazard assessments, accidental prevention measures, and emergency response plans, aimed at reducing risks to public health and the environment. This proactive approach reflects TIs ongoing commitment to safety, regulatory compliance and continuous improvement.

Texas Instruments is a global leader in semiconductor manufacturing, specializing in the production of analog, embedded processing and signal processing technologies. TI chips are ubiquitous in a wide range of industries including automotive, industrial, aerospace, communication and personal computing to name just a few. TI chips are manufactured in 200mm and 300mm wafer factories that use various chemical processes to pattern, etch, deposit, and dope microscopic electronic structures. Texas Instruments  LFAB, located in Lehi Utah, is one of TIs advanced 300mm fabs producing next generation electronics.

Situated at the heart of Silicon Slopes, LFAB is bounded by Lehi City, Highland City and the southern slope of Traverse Mountain. At full capacity, LFAB will produce 10s of millions of chips daily in its 620 sqft of clean room space. This level of production can only be achieved through storage, distribution and use of hazardous chemicals in large quantities; in some cases, exceeding EPA RMP quantity thresholds and posing a risk to surrounding communities in the case of a catastrophic failure. At this time, chemicals of concern include:

Anhydrous Ammonia, CAS Number 7664-41-7: The anhydrous ammonia distribution system consists of one 12,000 gallon storage tank, two redundant 30-kilowatt va

porizers, a tanker slip with fill stand, control system and associated piping to the ammonium hydroxide blender where concentrations are diluted below regulatory thresholds. The maximum quantity in this process is greater than EPA's RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds listed in Appendix 1 of 40 CFR 68.130 and OSHA's PSM threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds listed in Appendix A of 29 CFR 1910.119. As such, TI manages the anhydrous ammonia system as a program level 3.

TI is committed to preventing accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. This system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with all applicable regulations. TI employees and contractors having duties related to the bulk systems are thoroughly trained on applicable tasks and procedures. Additionally, TI maintains a written emergency response program and has trained emergency responders on-site to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment. 

The prevention program focuses on hazard analysis, operating procedures, employee training, and maintenance activities and formalizes these practices into our ESH management system. 

Hazard Analysis: A formal Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was conducted to assess the upset conditions the equipment may present, the controls in place, and the adequacies of these controls to prevent events with high or catastrophic potential. The type of PHA used to analysis the anhydrous ammonia is system was a Hazard and Operability Study. 

Process Controls: Numerous process controls and safeguards have been included in the design and operation of the equipment associated with the chemical processes covered by the PSM/RMP Rule including: 
	Fenced manufacturing site with controlled access
	Controlled and limited access to the bulk chemical storage area
	Closed circuit camera monitoring of the bulk chemical storage area
	Multiple ambient toxic gas monitoring devices for ammonia
	Automatic or manually activated Water fog / sprayer system for ammoni

a vapor suppression
	Emergency exits with panic hardware
	Lightning protection and building reference ground protect the facility from lightning and static discharge
	 24/7 supervised fire alarm panel
	Exhaust scrubber for planned discharges
	Pressure relief devices including tank pressure relief valves, hydrostatic relief valves and bleeder valves
	Excess flow control devices
	Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)
	Control valves fail closed if pneumatic pressure is lost or shutoff
	Safe work practices and training for employees who operate and maintain the bulk chemical storage area, and trained onsite emergency responders. 

Operating Procedures: TI RFAB maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, and normal shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process. 

Employee Training: All employees involved in operating and maintaining chemical processes covered by the PSM/RMP Rule, including supervisors and managers, and temporary or intermittent workers are provided initial training before their work on the covered process begins as well as refresher training. 

Maintenance Activities: TI  LFAB maintains written procedures for maintaining process equipment so that it operates safely. Equipment associated with the chemical processes covered by the PSM/RMP Rule are periodically tested and/or inspected to ensure safe operation of process equipment, following recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.

Texas Instruments  LFAB has not experienced releases or incidents involving the managed substances. Incidents involving substances managed in regards to PSM/RMP requirements will be promptly investigated and reported in accordance with regulatory requirements.

TI maintains a written emergency response program and trained

emergency responders to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including: 
	Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, 
	Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation,
	Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, 
	Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements, and 
	Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment. 

TI has coordinated emergency response efforts with local emergency responders (fire departments, LEPC, etc.) and has provided training to facilitate an understanding of the regulated chemicals and process. 

The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.

On-going programs, such as process hazard analysis re-evaluations, internal and external compliance audits, and training, continually aim to improve process safety. TI  LFAB maintains an ESH management system that is certified to both ISO14001:2015 & ISO45001:2018. This ensures implementation of a successful safety and environmental management program that includes elements required under the RMP and PSM rules throughout the entire plant.
